title: Why is shoplifting rampant in San Francisco in fall 2020? What caused it? Why are so many pharmacies, convenience stores, and similar retailers closing there? - Quora

response.answer_text: I would imagine there are two reasons: one, the vast homeless population, and two, the fact that policies of the city have been homeless-friendly to the point of talking about “excusing” shoplifting based on the fact that people need things, and if they don’t have money, then they just have to take them. Yes, that’s really what has been talked about. So clearly, this is becoming a very unfriendly town to your average retailer. What with the lockdown restrictions piled on top of the city’s leniency toward the homeless and vagrant population, it would have to be pure hell to be a retailer in the SF area right about now. So, they’re leaving. I probably would too.

Store closings/pandemic/Occam/do the math. San Francisco near bottom of shoplifting list: “The Cities Where People Shoplift The Most Have One Thing In Common Ashley Lutz Jun 6, 2012, 3:25 PM  Flickr / Kay Gaensler The National Retail Federation asked 125 corporations which cities ranked highest for organized shoplifting — where people don't just steal a single item, but take in bulk and rake in the profits. The areas share a common theme: large, national roadways that provide easy access to stores and a good escape route.
